GSA pass no confidence motion in Higher Ed Partners

12/02/2023

Nouse covers the Graduate Students' Association's lack of confidence in Higher Ed Partners

Image by BEN JORDAN

By Chris Stapleton

ON 12 JANUARY 2023 the Graduate Studentsâ€™ Association (GSA)Â passed a motion of no confidence inÂ Higher Ed Partners (HEP), the thirdÂ party who are responsible for theÂ marketing, recruitment and studentÂ support functions of the University ofÂ Yorkâ€™s online postgraduate courses.

The GSA aims to call on the University to cease working with HigherÂ Ed Partners as soon as possible and toÂ request a review on their partnership.Â Ten people voted on the GSA CouncilÂ which consists of Sabbatical OfficersÂ and Part-Time Officers. Out of the tenÂ Councillors who voted, nine peopleÂ voted in favour while one voted to abstain.

The University provides 13Â part-time online taught postgraduateÂ courses in partnership with HEP but,Â in particular, the GSAâ€™s vote of no confidence was impacted by the missoldÂ Msc Computer Science course refundsÂ whichÂ NouseÂ reported on last March.

In this fiasco, an Office of theÂ Independent Adjudicator for HigherÂ Education report dated 4 FebruaryÂ 2022 verified that students had beenÂ mis-sold the course and justified the refund for students. Complaints includedÂ oversubscribed courses and misleadingÂ marketing in the course description.

Nouse has used direct evidenceÂ from this recent motion of no confidence and has also spoken to the GSAâ€™sÂ Online Student Officer about their experience with Higher Ed Partners.The motion of no confidence explicitly calls attention to issues withÂ enrolled studentsâ€™ data.

The motion describes, â€œthere have been reports fromÂ students about the data HEP holds notÂ being kept up to date, and examples ofÂ emails and phone calls sent by them toÂ students exceeding the level expectedÂ by the contact strategy agreed with theÂ University.â€

In further detail, the motion explained that, â€œstudent reps have identified 12 incidents of inappropriate processing of personal data by HEP in anÂ 11-week period during 2022â€. WithinÂ the motion, it also details HEPâ€™s response to these data issues. They explained that their â€œdata quality is operating beyond 99.5 percentâ€ and theyÂ â€œbelieve this is within reasonable tolerances of what can be expected of a business of this scaleâ€.

NouseÂ asked the GSAâ€™s OnlineÂ Student Officer to explain examplesÂ of such data breaches. They explained,Â â€œstudents who are enrolled on modulesÂ are still getting reminders from HEPÂ to enrol, so suggesting that studentsÂ havenâ€™t paid their tuition fees, becauseÂ the data hasnâ€™t moved from the University.

Students are opting out of marketing emails and then HEP are optingÂ them back in.â€ They explained that although theÂ University insisted that these arenâ€™tÂ sales calls but admin reminders, theÂ persistent emails and phone calls feltÂ like sales.Â They added, â€œBut HEP are actively recruiting telesales people â€“ if [theÂ emails and phone calls] are not sales,Â why are HEP recruiting telesales? It isÂ for sales.â€

Indeed, the motion also highlightsÂ this same sentiment, describing howÂ â€œHEP has advertised vacancies for â€˜In-bound and Outbound Telesales Representativesâ€™, which includes answeringÂ questions about courses, meeting salesÂ targets and facilitating future salesâ€.

The University and HEP responded that â€œHigher Ed Partners and theÂ University of York take data protectionÂ very seriously and we both adhere to theÂ highest industry standards. StudentsÂ raised a small number of concerns withÂ us in June 2022 and as a result we haveÂ made improvements to our systems andÂ data quality processes. If any studentÂ has any concerns about how their dataÂ is processed we would encourage themÂ to get in touch with their Student Success Coordinator.â€

Nouse asked the GSAâ€™s OnlineÂ Student Officer about their thoughtsÂ on HEPâ€™s marketing. Indeed, the motion of no confidence draws attention to this sameÂ point, describing, â€œThe publicly accessible marketing material has notÂ drawn attention to the potential for anÂ unusually long course extension of 16Â months, which is incongruous to theÂ other marketing statements of â€˜on yourÂ own termsâ€™ and â€˜without putting yourÂ life on holdâ€™.
